page.title: 01Sth of Pinmore,
page.content: North of Pinwherry The land consists of cultivated grass rotating with cereals. The latter being barley or oats. Until 15-20 yrs ago, farming was mainly dairy with a few sheep. Currently there are only beef, producing cattle and a large increase in sheep flocks Through grids 1,2,3 and 5 passes the River Stinchar en route to Firth of Clyde. It has a large peat residue and popular salmon and trout fishing, also brown trout. Fishing rights are leased by indivuduals from the Crown Commissioners, Edinburgh. There are small pockets of woodlands, mostly well established confiers. In grid 11 exists a five year old plantation, in grid 1, 5 acres are being planted with beech and oak. Local amenities are none. TV reception is poor being obtainable only from Ulster.
